On october 1, 2013
Blaire

As far as I can see, this forum lacks a riddle thread. And that's terrible. Anyway, I'm making this thread so that people can present riddles for other people to solve. When is a riddle is solved, and the answer is confirmed by the riddler, then the one who solved the riddle may either present the next riddle, or choose to abstain, in which case anyone can present a riddle. Anyone. That's singular. If any riddle stays up too long without being solved, or an answer is confirmed by popular vote and not denied by the poser of the riddle within twenty four hours, then we can move on to the next riddle. However, primarily I intend this thread to deal with one riddle until it's solved, before moving to the next riddle. Note: This is a thread for riddles, not puns. If I hear one more person tell me that you halves make a hole and you crawl through it to escape, then I will personally disembowel them with a chunk of concrete rebar. Because I care. As thread-maker I will present the first riddle. If you've heard this exact iteration before, then I encourage you to let someone else new to it to get it. There may be multiple correct answers. You land on an island. You know that on this island there are two tribes. One tribe is pleasant and peaceful and helpful and will help you if you go to their village, but will always lie. The other tribe is honorable and brave and strong and always tells the truth, but are cannibals and will eat you if you go to their village. After getting off the beach and heading up a very convenient path for a bit, you come to a fork in the road. One path leads to the cannibal's village, and the other leads to the friendly folks' village. At this crossroad stands a native. He is from one of the two tribes. What question can you ask the native to ensure that you know which path to take? You may only ask one question.

Frankly, I don't think that answer makes much sense. Let's say today's Sunday. Sure, you can rule out next Sunday because by the time Saturday comes, you know the date of your death prior to the date. However, on Friday, you won't know whether the psychopath kills you today or tomorrow. If he kills you today, you haven't disproved anything. If he waits until tomorrow, you'll figure out he'll kill you on Saturday, but you can only figure that out on that day, in which case, you haven't disproved anything.
On october 5, 2013
NERON

Full AnswerYeah, I know the logic smells funny.
It's because part one and two are both paradoxes. Similar to 'This statement is a lie'

Part one
On Sunday, it is the last day he can kill you.
Therefore, you must be killed today.
Therefore, it cannot be Sunday because you would know prior.

You can apply the same logic you used for Sunday to eliminate the entire week:

On Saturday, you know he cannot kill you on Sunday or any day after
Therefore, you must be killed today.
Therefore, it cannot be Saturday because you would know prior.

On Friday, you know he cannot kill you on Saturday or any day after
Therefore, you must be killed today.
Therefore, it cannot be Friday because you would know prior.

[...]
Therefore, it cannot be Monday because you would know prior.
Therefore, he cannot kill you this week yet still be able surprise you.

Part twoIf you think you've outsmarted him, you expect to live.
Therefore, when he kills you, you will be surprised.
The psychopath hasn't broken his word yet there is no escape this time.

On october 24, 2013
Blaire

I think it's pride. Though I could see an argument for sloth.
On october 24, 2013
NERON

Explain

On october 24, 2013
Blaire

Was hoping I wouldn't have to, but in a riddle with limited answers this is to be expected. Due to the nature of pride, the average man would not derive much pleasure from it; he is average, and has no exceptional status from which to feel pride. Pride is said to be the greatest of all sin, which explains the third line. The fifth line says "But I leave no room for other sins". This makes sense, as someone would not be proud of having sins. If one lacked the other sins, one would have cause for pride. If you cheat on pride with the other sins, you can no longer be proud of yourself, for you have dabbled in debauchery. For the last few lines, it mentions how the sin will not relieve you of your addictions. This is because, unlike the other sins, one doesn't really indulge in pride. It's more of a state of mind. One may succumb to sloth, act in anger, engage in envy, gorge in gluttony, grab greedily and lapse into lust, but one cannot actively commit pride. Pride doesn't act as a relief for one's stress or baser emotions, as the other sins do. And of course, the proud do not seek forgiveness, and a lapse from maintaining the standards from which one's pride is derived is unforgivable.

Here's a (hopefully) a simple one:

You are given 16 blocks. Each block is supposed to weigh 1 kg. However, one of the 16 blocks is slightly heavier than all the others while all the others are of equal weight. You are given a scale to help you determine the heavy block. You are allowed three scalings before you are forced to choose which block you think is the heavy one. Is it possible to be 100% accurate with three scalings? If so, is it possible to still be 100% accurate with fewer scalings? If it is not possible to be 100% accurate with three scalings, what is the minimum amount required? Explain your reasoning.

Blaire

I'm working under the assumption that you are able to see which group is heavier, which one would be able to do with a real scale. Take 10 and split them into two groups. Weigh the groups against each other. There are 2 possible results.

1. The groups are unequal in weight. Take the heavier 5 and sort them into 2 groups of 2 and set one aside. Weigh the 2 groups of 2 against each other. If they are equal in weight, the odd one out is the heavier weight. If the groups are uneven in weight take the heavier two and weigh them against each other. The heavier of those two is obviously the heavier.

2. The groups are equal in weight. In that case, split the remaining group of six into 3 groups of two. Weigh two of the groups against each other. If they are equal in weight, then weigh the remaining pair against each other, and the heavier of those two is the heavier weight. If the groups of two are unequal in weight, then take the heavier pair, split it in two, take those two, weight them against each other, then take the heavier weight. That weight is the heavier weight.

Mr. Black, Mr. Gray, and Mr. White are fighting in a truel. They each get a gun and take turns shooting at each other until only one person is left. Mr. Black, who hits his shot 1/3 of the time, gets to shoot first. Mr. Gray, who hits his shot 2/3 of the time, gets to shoot next, assuming he is still alive. Mr. White, who hits his shot all the time, shoots next, assuming he is also alive. The cycle repeats. If you are Mr. Black, where should you shoot first for the highest chance of survival?

Hint: think outside the box!

On november 14, 2013
NERON

Not shooting at all is the best option.
Grey has 2/3 chance of hitting someone; 1/2 chance of targeting you;
chance of death on round 1 = [2/3][1/2]= 1/3
White has a 2/3 chance of not being dead at this point; 1/2 chance of targeting you;
chance of death on round 2 = [2/3][1/2]= 1/3Best just let everyone kill each other.

Then again, Mr White probably has some mercury fulminate so you're dead anyways. Might as well go down shooting.

Alternative answer: Daylight savings time occurred, so they lost an hour, and he rode in a few minutes before midnight on Friday. Two days later minus the hour from Day light savings time, makes monday. Alternatively, the town is in two time zones.

On december 10, 2013
Blaire

Well, if we think of days as 24-hour periods, then he would be riding out of town two twenty-four hour periods later. Normally that would be two days, and even if he arrived 10 minutes before midnight Friday, the earliest he could leave would be 10 minutes before midnight Sunday. However, if the town was in two time zones, he could exit from the eastern side, and thus be in the next day, on Monday, rather than Sunday. Alternatively, he is doing this while Day Light Savings Time is occurring and loses an hour, thus allowing him to only spend 47 hours, but two full "days" in town.

On march 14, 2014
NERON

Ah but in reality, feathers are rarely white. This is the real trick in the riddle: feathers have variable lightness therefore we are looking for an object with variable lightness.

Superheated space shuttle reentry plates have a definite lightness value of 9 so you'd be wrong.

Despite their name, flaming bagel-shaped pieces of dark matter are not in fact 'dark'. They just have an unknown lightness value because such objects have never been measured for their lightness, among other things. And unlike 'fire' or 'air', you can hold flaming bagel-shaped pieces of dark matter, just not for long. Because holding burning objects for prolonged periods will cause burns. Also, ew bagels. I don't blame him for masquerading as a donut.

King chess pieces, They go sideways, and more often then not go backwards, but what counts as backwards? It could likely be this one.


Ladies and Gentlemen, it is one of these, but which one?

[5367939]

Imagine for a moment you had a hollow infinity symbol.

Suppose a liquid were to be flowing or 'something' were to be placed inside, such as an ant.

Let us define that movement of liquid [or ant] as forward and straight.

Now let us stand that symbol for infinity up <><> becomes 8

The earlier definition, and change of position means whatever it is is no longer traveling forward or straight; therefore, it must now be traveling backwards and sideways.

We have the number 8 right? yes

we have something literally [or figuratively] 'walking' underneath that 8? yes

We have 'always backward ..etc, etc.'? yes

imagine each 'curve' of the number 8 was defined as a 'row' of the singular number

'rows of eight' or 'rows of the number 8' if you will.

Regardless, Versatio's works much better than that because traveling on a mobius strip, an ant would not be traveling forward or straight [at any point in time] and it would also technically be traveling 'underneath the rows of the number 8'

since a mobius strip looks exactly like that number XD

I have so become an evil mastermind XD

On september 1, 2014
NERON

The earlier definition, and change of position means whatever it is is no longer traveling forward or straight; therefore, it must now be traveling backwards and sideways.No, the traveler in this case would be neither going forwards nor backwards. The traveler is not making progess in any direction. It's not going straight on three dimensions but 'traveling sideways' would imply the traveler is moving perpendicular to the strip, making 'traveling sideways' even less applicable than 'traveling straight'. Just because one thing is invalid does not mean the opposite is true.imagine each 'curve' of the number 8 was defined as a 'row' of the singular numberThe very definition of 'row' is 'a number of persons or things arranged in a line, especially a straight line'. Your 'row' is neither composed of more elementary objects nor straight so it fails both conditions needed for it to be considered a 'row'.

The Mbius strip answer doesn't fit completely either. One of it's defining characteristics is that a traveler will travel on the inside and outside surfaces simply by moving forward parallel to the edges. It wouldn't just be walking underneath the 'row of eight', it would be walking over it as well. This is what makes a Mbius strip a Mbius strip and not a simple loop.

[8356287]

The Mbius strip in Escher's woodcut is comprised of rows, lengthwise and cross-ways. A figure-eight made of rows satisfies the phrase "rows of eight."

"Never straight" is obviously true.

The remaining statements pertain to relative prepositions that lose their meaning in the context of navigating such a pseudo-paradoxical structure. If you are both inside and outside, then you are both above and beneath - it's all equally meaningless, or meaningful, however you want to look at it. Same for backward, forward, and sideways. It's hard to pin down their meaning here. So I guess it was a trick question! (Isn't that the definition of a riddle?)

So it's my turn then? Alright, I'll try to come up with something...

A crazy genius invented an Oracle Machine that could answer "yes or no" questions. But when it was built, it always gave the wrong answer. Trying again, a second model was built that would give the right answer half of the time. Finally, a third model was built that always gave the right answer.

The inventor offers to give you one of the machines. Obviously you would prefer machine #3. But machine #1 would also be fine, because you can simply take the opposite of every answer it gives. Machine #2 is clearly worthless.

Unfortunately, the crazy genius refuses to tell you which is which. However, you are allowed to ask any machine one question before you decide which to take. What do you ask?

This is NOT a hint, but I'll remind you how deductive logic works:

The riddle provides a set of facts. A random machine will answer your question, providing another fact. From these facts you can draw a logical conclusion that will allow you to avoid choosing machine #2.

Another reminder: The machine's answer is only reliable in 2 out of 3 cases, but your task is to narrow down the choice to 2 out of 3 machines.

FlawlessSin"will the answer to this question be the same as the answer to the next question i ask you?" (i dunno if someone already posted this, sorry if you have)

The Oracle Machine knows that you will not ask it another question because you can only ask it one question, unless you choose to take that machine. So the correct answer is "no" in most cases, which reduces to the opposite of the previous questions whose answers were "yes," and doesn't yield any reliable conclusion. If you choose to take the machine you ask, you still don't know whether it was #2.

On september 3, 2014
FlawlessSin

Machines are, randomly, A, B, and C.
Ask A if Machine B is older than C.
If the answer is yes, take C. If the answer is no, take B.
If A is the truthful one and B is the liar, the answer will be no. If A is the truthful one and C is the liar, the answer will be yes. In both instances, you take the liar.
If A is the middle Machine, it will not matter what it answers; you will take one of the other Machines.
If A is the liar and B is the truthful one the answer will be no. If A is the liar and C is the truthful one, the answer will be yes. In both instances you take the truthful one.

My riddle:


A group of people with assorted eye colors live on an island. They are all perfect logicians -- if a conclusion can be logically deduced, they will do it instantly. No one knows the color of their eyes. Every night at midnight, a ferry stops at the island. Any islanders who have figured out the color of their own eyes then leave the island, and the rest stay. Everyone can see everyone else at all times and keeps a count of the number of people they see with each eye color (excluding themselves), but they cannot otherwise communicate. Everyone on the island knows all the rules in this paragraph.

On this island there are 100 blue-eyed people, 100 brown-eyed people, and the Guru (she happens to have green eyes). So any given blue-eyed person can see 100 people with brown eyes and 99 people with blue eyes (and one with green), but that does not tell him his own eye color; as far as he knows the totals could be 101 brown and 99 blue. Or 100 brown, 99 blue, and he could have red eyes.

The Guru is allowed to speak once (let's say at noon), on one day in all their endless years on the island. Standing before the islanders, she says the following:

"I can see someone who has blue eyes."

Who leaves the island, and on what night?

(This is googlable, please don't ruin it for others who wish to try to solve it)

[8356287]

RIGHT! Extending from the logic in my last attempt, if there are THREE blue-eyed people visible, then no one would leave on the first night. But each of the blue-eyed people would expect BOTH of the others to leave on the SECOND night, UNLESS their eyes are ALSO blue. So all three will leave the island on the THIRD night.

This can be extended to any number of visible blue-eyed people, which means that the hypothetical scenario of only a subset being visible is completely unnecessary!

I believe the solution is:

All of the blue-eyed people will leave on the hundredth night. No one else will leave.
On september 3, 2014
Blaire

I've kinda sorta seen this type of thing, but not this riddle specifically. Closest I've seen is that one test question or that one multi-color hats problem, so I'm not counting it.

Everyone with blue eyes can leave the island... eventually. To be more specific, all 100 blue-eyed folk leave the island on the 100th day. To illustrate this, let's simplify then complicate the problem.
If we had 1 blue-eyed islander, they could instantly figure out they have blue-eyes and leave the first night. EZ. The problem really starts when you have 2 islanders. Night one, neither can go, because they don't know their eye-color. However, the next day, they each separately realize that the other blue-eyed islander is still there. Why would their fellow still be there? Only if they themself had blue-eyes too. This concluded, they both leave the second night. With three islanders, I'm going to set up a pattern. Basically, the blue-eyed islanders assume they do not have blue eyes until proven otherwise (what else are they going to do). So let's take the perspective of islander 3 in this mini-scenario I cooked up. "Oh, ho, ho! Those two fools will figure out that they both have blue eyes the second day, after having seen the other one doesn't leave on night one, and then both leave night two." Day 3: "Wait, they didn't leave night 2. Guess that means they couldn't use that logic to leave... which means there must be another blue-eyed person. However, this person is extremely handsome and an absolutely flawless logician. Namely, me! Oh ho ho!" All three island bums make this conclusion at the same. Essentially, as you increase the number of people from 3 to 100, this pattern keeps occurring. They are able to determine that they have blue-eyes based by the other islanders not leaving the island on the night whose number is equivalent to the number of blue-eyed islanders they see. Therefore, 4 blue-eyed islanders would leave on night 4, 5 on night 5, and so on, until all 100 blue-eyed islanders leave the island on the night 100 (aka the 100th midnight after the Guru's terrible hint). I'll do 4 blue-eyed islanders too, just to illustrate my point. Basically with 4 people, the blue-eyed bozos use the logic that is used with 3 people to conclude that since the blue-eyed people didn't all leave on night 3, they must also have blue-eyes. This continues, so on and so forth, to 100.

Night 101, a package arrives on the island from the ferry containing a mirror from the blue-eyed islanders. The brown-eyed islanders use it to figure out their eye color. No one allows the Guru to use it, because she screwed them.

I swear I didn't Google this. I visualized about two dozen different configurations before I found "a" solution. (I don't know if there might be any other solutions.) First I tried a bunch of single-seed-per-location configurations, but eventually realized that there must be multiple seeds in some places. A pair of seeds at each vertex of a pentagon.

[8356287]

Draw a five-sided shape. It doesn't matter if it's sloppy, as long as it is made of five lines that all join end-to-end. Then draw a big, fat dot at the five corners where the lines meet. Each dot represents TWO seeds. This forms five lines with 4 seeds each.

Of course, flowers don't grow straight up, they usually lean a bit to one side. But this would ruin every other possible solution too.

You are in a foreign land, and you are currently on death row. On the day of the execution at 11:30 AM, the prison guards blindfold you, tie your wrists together behind your back, and take you outside. When you are placed in front of the magistrate, he offers you one last chance to live. Two open boxes of pebbles from inside a nearby building will be placed behind you. One box contains pebbles painted black and is placed behind one of your hands. The other box contains pebbles painted white and is placed behind your other hand. You must hold up one pebble up high within one hour. If you choose a white pebble, you will be pardoned and can leave. If you choose a black pebble, do not pick up a pebble at all, or in any way try to remove your blindfold, you will be executed. All pebbles are identical in every way except the colour. You can do whatever you want with the pebbles. There is no way to use the pebbles to escape except by holding up a white pebble within one hour. How can you guarantee you will escape death?

On october 3, 2014
EoNightcore

In 50 BC, at his Proconsular term's expiry, the Pompey-led Senate ordered Caesar's return to Rome and the disbanding of his army, and forbade his standing for election in absentia for a second consulship; because of that, Caesar thought he would be prosecuted and rendered politically marginal if he entered Rome without consular immunity or his army; to wit, Pompey accused him of insubordination and treason.

"On 10 January 49 BC, leading one legion, the Legio XIII Gemina, General Julius Caesar crossed the Rubicon River, the boundary between the Cisalpine Gaul province to the north and Italy proper to the south, a legally-proscribed action forbidden to any army-leading general. The proscription protected the Roman Republic from a coup d'tat; thus, Caesar's military action began a civil war.

This act of war on the Roman Republic by Caesar led to widespread approval amongst the Roman civilians, who believed him a hero. The historical records differ about which decisive comment Caesar made on crossing the Rubicon: one report is Alea iacta est (usually translated as "The die is cast" )."

Take 9 from 6, 10 from 9, 50 from 40 and leave 6. How can this be?
On november 28, 2014
[8550239]

six- ix=s
ix-x=i
xl-l=x

(but why isn't six vi?)

oh wait maybe -3 -1+10=6 woops
On november 28, 2014
Ian_

Correct!

Also, Six is already all letters, so your just subtracting the letters of SIX from 9 (IX) which equals S, then X from IX which equals I, and finally, L from XL leaving X. Putting S from the first equation, I from 2nd, and X from 3rd, you get SIX.

Ian_

Ok, since no one has put one up within the past few days., i'll do one.

Mr. Black, Mr. Gray, and Mr. White are fighting in a truel. They each get a gun and take turns shooting at each other until only one person is left. Mr. Black, who hits his shot 1/3 of the time, gets to shoot first. Mr. Gray, who hits his shot 2/3 of the time, gets to shoot next, assuming he is still alive. Mr. White, who hits his shot all the time, shoots next, assuming he is also alive. The cycle repeats. If you are Mr. Black, where should you shoot first for the highest chance of survival?
On december 1, 2014
Addem-Up

The ground. If you kill Gray, White will kill you. If you kill White, Gray has a 2/3 chance to kill you. If you kill no one, White and Gray will both try to kill each other, being the most threatening to each other. That leaves you with the first shot next round.

On december 4, 2014
[8356287]
BlaireHonestly, I didn't get most of the riddle

Really? Alright, I'll go through it line-by-line:


1. "Thing" is the root node in the taxonomy of all things. Everything is a thing.

2. Things are certainly "present in large numbers"

3-4. "Thing" is often used as a generic place-holder word, referring to something that can only be determined by context. Example: "I love this thing!"

5-8. As notable exceptions to being "seldom specific," I listed four examples of the word used as a specific name for fairly well-known fictional characters, all correctly identified by Blaire and Addem-Up.

9. Returning to taxonomy, the subcategories of "Thing" form a hierarchy. Their meanings stack up. Example: a life-form is a thing, a plant is a life-form, a tree is a plant, an oak is a tree, a pin oak is an oak, and the tree in my front yard is a pin oak. Each of these things can be identified as any category above it; each is ultimately a thing.

10-11. Since everything is a thing, it would be silly to enumerate all of the specific "identities" of Thing - they're hardly countable.

12. Continuing the thought of enumerating identities, it would be reasonable to eliminate the "boring" usage of the word as a generic place-holder or taxonomic root, and instead only count the instances when it refers to something specific, such as the four examples given.
